awd_titl_txt: CAS: Collaborative Research: Separating Electronic and Geometric Effects in Compound Catalysts: Examining Unique Selectivities for Hydrogenolysis on Transition Metal Phosphides
awd_abstract_narration:
The conversion of biomass, shale, and petroleum feedstocks into value-added fuels and chemicals requires costly and rare metal catalysts to speed up the chemical reactions. This design of less expensive and more earth abundant catalysts is a major challenge to materials chemists and engineers. Combining inexpensive elements with rare metals can reduce costs while maintaining or improving catalyst performance. Previously, this strategy has been limited because the dependence of the performance and stability on the structure and composition of these catalysts was not understood. In this project, Dr. Hibbitts (University of Florida), Dr. Flaherty (University of Illinois – Urbana-Champaign), and Dr. Plaisance (Louisiana State University) are collaborating to understand the fundamental behavior of metal catalysts with an initial focus on metal phosphide materials. This understanding will guide the design of future catalysts that provide targeted improvements in reaction rates and selectivities of interest to the chemical industry. Drs. Hibbitts, Flaherty, and Plaisance participate in outreach activities that excite and motivate students into studying topics within STEM. Summer internships, mentor-mentee formations, and interactive workshops are just some of the activities these faculty use at their respective institutions to increase the size and diversity of the future chemistry workforce.

Funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is enabling a multi-investigator collaboration among Dr. Hibbitts (University of Florida), Dr. Flaherty (University of Illinois – Urbana-Champaign), and Dr. Plaisance (Louisiana State University).  These researchers will develop a fundamental understanding of how the electronic and geometric effects of P-atoms in transition metal phosphides lead to regioselective rupture of C–O bonds in biomass-derived oxygenates. Transition metal phosphides are stable, inexpensive, and productive catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation because they selectively cleave sterically-hindered C–O bonds that are difficult to activate with other metal catalysts. These C–O rupture pathways produce value-added chemicals from biomass molecules. A broad understanding of this class of materials and guiding structure-function relationships do not currently exist but will be addressed in this project.  Where possible, synthesis and characterization of these materials will validate density functional theory (DFT) predictions and models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Transition metal phosphides, alloy, and other isostructural compounds created in the form of nanoparticles are stable, cheap, and attractive catalysts to valorize biomass-derived feedstocks, which is a critical capability necessary to sustain production of platform chemicals and fuels from domestic resources. This project developed fundamental understanding of the electronic and structure properties of these materials with particular focus on the atomic structure present at surfaces. The arrangements of these atoms determine the preference of these catalysts to cleave distinct bonds within organic molecules during hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis processes crucial for upgrading reactions.

Developing structure-function relationships to deconvolute the effects of integrating phosphorus atoms and secondary metals within nanoparticles of a host transition metal, however, is limited by the small number of previously synthesized materials that are isostructural. The limited number of materials prompts us to examine materials that have (i) not yet been synthesized, (ii) not been computationally examined at relevant conditions, or , (iii) examined in a manner to understand the influence of atomic orbital structures on surface chemistry that mediates catalytic reactions.

We used a combination of computational, experimental, and theoretical methods to develop this knowledge. Specific achievements include advances in synthesis methods to produce these forms of nanoparticles with the desired structure and composition.  These methods utilize directed liquid-phase chemical methods to deposit the individual elements upon high surface area supports with close proximity between the individual elements to allow formation of compounds in a scalable manner.  These materials have been examined with computational methods, which demonstrated the specific organization of transition metal and secondary elements at surfaces result in large differences in binding configurations and reactivity toward distinct C-C, C-H, and C-O bonds within small molecules. Complementary spectroscopic and structural characterization methods demonstrate that the surfaces exposed on these compounds bind probe molecules (e.g., hydrogen, oxygen, and carbon monoxide) at coverages and binding energies highly sensitive to surface composition and structure. Furthermore, these structures evolve in response to the presence of organic reactants.

These findings provide specific understanding of the compounds of primary focus. More broadly, however, the methodologies developed are transferable to other combinations of materials and catalytic chemistries. Consequently, these tools will be integrated into future investigations of hydrocarbon and oxygenate conversions.

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2025
Modified by: David Flaherty
